Research consistently shows that quality early education leads to improved academic and social outcomes, reducing achievement gaps and breaking the cycle of poverty. üí™ üéì Investing in early childhood education ensures that every child has a fair start in life and paves the way for a more equitable society. It's time for an FCRO Spotlight! Today we would like to highlight Zach Short, Senior Education Specialist for Upward Bound and IIB9 Board Member. Q) How long have you been a board member with the FCRO? ‚≠êÔ∏èA) Seven months. Q) What are your personal hobbies? ‚≠êÔ∏èA) Outside of my role in education and volunteering with the FCRO, I'm an avid collector of board games! There is nothing I enjoy more than spending some time with my partner Jodi and her family playing the latest Monopoly game. Q) What is your all time favorite movie, band/musician, or TV series? ‚≠êÔ∏èA) Without a doubt, my favorite band of all time has to be The Beatles. Very clearly there is a reason why they are regarded as the greatest of all time! Q) Give a fun fact about yourself! ‚≠êÔ∏èA) I went to the same elementary school as Jamie Lynn Spears. So theoretically, if they had waited a few more years, the show might have been called "Zach 101!" Q) Why do you feel the FCRO's mission is important? ‚≠êÔ∏èA) Every child deserves an advocate in their life, but unfortunately, the reality is that only a select few do. In order to ensure that our children have the opportunity to develop into healthy adults, they need intentional guidance and supervision. And that's what the Foster Care Review Office manages to do. They bring a number of diverse individuals from the community, guided under one mission, to ensure the youth of our community are holistically supported. In that sense, the individuals of the FCRO are the greatest advocates for the next generations of Nebraskans. Q) What do you consider your greatest accomplishment or what is the most rewarding part of your work? ‚≠êÔ∏èA) I think the most rewarding part of serving as a member of the FCRO is being able to meet the advocates for the children we work with. Every so often, I read a case of tragedy only to see the silver lining at the end. A foster parent, or maybe a social worker, truly puts in the effort to make a significant change in a child's life. In one sense or another, that person is actively saving a child's future. And being able to later check-in with these wonderful individuals and offer them some form of appreciation...Well, that's just the best feeling in the world.

Martin Luther King Jr. Day is a powerful occasion for early childhood classrooms to explore themes of love, diversity, and inclusion in an age-appropriate manner. Here are some engaging ways to teach our little ones about this remarkable leader: üìöEngaging Story-time: Introduce MLK Jr.'s life through age-appropriate books emphasizing his values of fairness, equality, and friendship. Books like "The Colors of Us" or "All Are Welcome" beautifully showcase the beauty of diversity. üé®Creative Activities: Encourage art projects that echo MLK Jr.'s messages. From crafting peace doves using handprints to creating 'dream clouds' where kids draw or write their hopes for a better world, these activities inspire creativity while teaching important values. ü§ùRole-Playing for Values: Foster discussions and role-playing scenarios focused on kindness and fairness. Help children understand these concepts through simple, relatable situations like sharing toys or helping friends. üé∂Musical Exploration: Use music and movement to reinforce the themes of peace, unity, and friendship. Songs and dances that celebrate diversity and love can be a fun way to engage children while imparting meaningful messages. üíïSpread Acts of Kindness: Encourage children to perform acts of kindness, such as sharing, helping, or expressing gratitude. Highlight how these small acts contribute to making the world a better place. ü´∂Simple Language & Family Involvement: Use age-appropriate language to explain MLK Jr.'s legacy of love and equality. Encourage parents to continue these discussions at home, offering suggestions for activities that reinforce these lessons. Celebrating MLK Jr. is not just about one day; it‚Äôs about embracing his teachings throughout the year. By incorporating these activities, we honor his legacy and inspire a future generation committed to love, fairness, and equality. Share with us your favorite ways to celebrate this special day with our young minds! #MLKDay #TeachingLove #PreschoolEducation #InclusionMatters #DiversityAndInclusion #EarlyEducation

2023 was a banner year for Babson College and entrepreneurship education. Babson was named the 10th best college in the United States by The Wall Street Journal and retained our place atop U.S. News & World Report‚Äôs entrepreneurship rankings for the 27th and 30th consecutive time at the undergraduate and graduate levels. We also eclipsed the $500 million mark of our ambitious campaign and now elevated our goal once again to a total of $750 million. These rankings and the generosity of our donors, alumni, and friends signal that the world is recognizing and validating the power of entrepreneurial leadership. As our world faces numerous challenges and continuing social divide, #EntrepreneurialLeaders can play a distinct role in bridging gaps and impacting communities around the world. Entrepreneurial leaders think beyond what it takes to start a business. Being an entrepreneurial leader is about building relationships and remaining open to new ideas and ways of thinking. While that thought process is crucial in the business world, it has endless promise to impact how we lead and treat one another, too. Entrepreneurial leadership‚Äîpromoting innovative thinking and seeing no challenge as too big to overcome‚Äîhas untold potential to bring people together, no matter our differences. It's my hope that in 2024, more people will understand and embrace #EntrepreneurialLeadership and recognize that anyone can be an entrepreneur. Doing so will allow communities around the world to see the challenges facing society as opportunities to unite for a better tomorrow. Whether that manifests in new ways of approaching sustainability or championing diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging, or it leads to new and innovative technologies and applications of artificial intelligence that solve big and small problems, the world will benefit from an influx in entrepreneurial leaders.
